page.title: The Wolf of Wall Street (2013 film)

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = The Wolf of Wall Street | image = The Wolf of Wall Street (2013).png | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Martin Scorsese]] | producer = {{Plain list| * Martin Scorsese * [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] * [[Riza Aziz]] * [[Joey McFarland]] * [[Emma Tillinger Koskoff]] }} | screenplay = [[Terence Winter]] | based on = {{Based on|''[[The Wolf of Wall Street (book)|The Wolf of Wall Street]]''|[[Jordan Belfort]]}} | narrator = <!--- In-character voice overs are NOT the same as narrators. DO NOT ADD DICAPRIO! ---> | starring = {{plain list| * Leonardo DiCaprio * [[Jonah Hill]] * [[Margot Robbie]] * [[Matthew McConaughey]] * [[Kyle Chandler]] * [[Rob Reiner]] * [[Jon Bernthal]] * [[Jon Favreau]] * [[Jean Dujardin]] }} | cinematography = [[Rodrigo Prieto]] | editing = [[Thelma Schoonmaker]] | production companies = {{Plain list | * [[Red Granite Pictures]] * [[Appian Way Productions]] * [[Martin Scorsese|Sikelia Productions]] * EMJAG Productions }} | distributor = [[Paramount Pictures]]<!-- Main distributor was Paramount according to the poster and trailers --> | released = {{Film date|2013|12|17|[[Ziegfeld Theatre (1969)|Ziegfeld Theatre]]|2013|12|25|United States}} | runtime = 180 minutes<!--- Theatrical runtime: 179:55. RUNTIME ROUNDS UP ---><ref>{{cite web| url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/wolf-wall-street-film | title=''The Wolf of Wall Street'' (18) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=December 12, 2013 | accessdate=October 17, 2014}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $100 million<ref name="mojo" /> | gross = <!-- Remember to change accessdate and article below -->$392 million<ref name="mojo">{{cite web |title = The Wolf of Wall Street (2013)|url= http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=wolfofwallstreet.htm | publisher = [[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate= October 27, 2014}}</ref> }} '''''The Wolf of Wall Street''''' is a 2013 American [[biographical film| biographical]] [[black comedy]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/10579726/The-Wolf-of-Wall-Street-is-the-modern-equivalent-of-a-Shakespeare-play.html|title=The Wolf of Wall Street is the modern equivalent of a Shakespearean history play|first=Philip|last=Horne|date=October 4, 2017|accessdate=October 4, 2017|website=Telegraph.co.uk}}</ref> [[crime film|crime]] film directed by [[Martin Scorsese]] and written by [[Terence Winter]], based on the [[The Wolf of Wall Street (book)|memoir of the same name]] by [[Jordan Belfort]]. It recounts Belfort's perspective on his career as a stockbroker in [[New York City]] and how his firm [[Stratton Oakmont]] engaged in rampant corruption and fraud on [[Wall Street]] that ultimately led to his downfall. [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] (who was also a producer) stars as Belfort, with [[Jonah Hill]] as his business partner and friend Donnie Azoff, [[Margot Robbie]] as his wife Naomi Lapaglia and [[Kyle Chandler]] as Patrick Denham, the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] agent who tries to bring him down. [[Matthew McConaughey]], [[Rob Reiner]], [[Jon Favreau]], [[Joanna Lumley]] and [[Jean Dujardin]] also star. The film marks the [[Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio|director's fifth collaboration with DiCaprio]], after ''[[Gangs of New York]]'' (2002), ''[[The Aviator (2004 film)|The Aviator]]'' (2004), ''[[The Departed]]'' (2006) and ''[[Shutter Island (film)|Shutter Island]]'' (2010), as well as his second collaboration with Winter after the television series ''[[Boardwalk Empire]]'' (2010–14).
''The Wolf of Wall Street'' premiered in New York City on December 17, 2013, and was released in the United States on December 25, 2013, distributed by [[Paramount Pictures]]. The film was the first to be released entirely through [[digital distribution]]. It was a major commercial success, grossing more than $392 million worldwide during its original theatrical run to become Scorsese's highest-grossing film and the 17th-highest-grossing film of 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?view2=worldwide&yr=2013&p=.htm|title=2013 Yearly Box Office Results|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref> The film was controversial for its morally ambiguous depiction of events, explicit sexual content, extreme profanity, depiction of hard drug use and the [[Animals in film and television|use of animals]] during production. The film also caused controversy due to accusations that it was financed by illegally obtained funds from [[1Malaysia Development Berhad]] (1MDB).<ref name="auto">{{cite news| url = https://www.malaysiakini.com/news/336199 | title = WSJ: US$155m of 1MDB funds went to ‘Wolf of Wall Street’ |website=Malaysiakini.com|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2017/09/red-granite-settlement-1mdb-corruption-scandal-1202170872/|title=Red Granite Settles With U.S. Government Over 2 Films As Part Of 1MDB Case|last=Busch|first=Patrick Hipes, Anita|date=2017-09-15|work=Deadline|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en-US}}</ref>
The film received mostly positive reviews from critics, with praise for Scorsese's direction, the comedic performance of DiCaprio and the fast-paced and consistent humor. The film was [[List of accolades received by The Wolf of Wall Street (2013 film)|nominated for several awards]] including five nominations at the [[86th Academy Awards|86th Academy Awards ceremony]]: [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]], [[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]] and [[Academy Award for Best Writing (Adapted Screenplay)|Best Adapted Screenplay]], as well as [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] and [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]] nominations for DiCaprio and Hill, respectively. The film did not win in any category, although DiCaprio did win [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor - Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actor – Musical or Comedy]] at the [[71st Golden Globe Awards]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/golden-globes-2014-leonardo-dicaprio-wins-best-actor-for-the-wolf-of-wall-street-9055662.html|title=Golden Globes 2014: Leonardo DiCaprio wins Best Actor for The Wolf of|date=2014-01-13|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> where the film was also nominated for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture - Musical or Comedy|Best Picture – Musical or Comedy]]. It was also recognized by numerous other awards ceremonies, as well as guilds and critics' associations.
==Plot== In 1987, [[Jordan Belfort]] procures a job as a Wall Street stockbroker for [[L.F. Rothschild]], employed under Mark Hanna, who quickly entices him with the sex and drugs fueled stockbroker culture and passes on his idea that a stockbroker's only goal is to make money for himself. Jordan soon finds his career terminated following [[Black Monday (1987)|Black Monday]] and takes a job at a [[Boiler room (business)|boiler room brokerage firm]] on Long Island that specializes in [[penny stock]]s. Thanks to his aggressive pitching style and the high commissions, Jordan makes a small fortune.
Jordan befriends his neighbor, Donnie Azoff, and the two found their own company. They recruit several of Jordan's friends, whom Jordan trains in the art of the "hard sell". The basic method of the firm is a [[pump and dump]] scam. To cloak this, Jordan gives the firm the respectable-sounding name of [[Stratton Oakmont]]. After an exposé in ''[[Forbes]]'', hundreds of ambitious young financiers flock to his company. Jordan becomes immensely successful and slides into a decadent lifestyle of prostitutes and drugs. He has an affair with a woman named Naomi Lapaglia. When his wife finds out, Jordan divorces her and marries Naomi. Meanwhile, the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]] and the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] begin investigating Stratton Oakmont. Jordan illegally makes $22 million in three hours upon securing the [[Initial public offering|IPO]] of [[Steve Madden (company)|Steve Madden]]. This brings him and his firm further to the attention of the FBI. To hide his money, Jordan opens a [[Swiss bank account]] with corrupt banker Jean-Jacques Saurel in the name of Naomi's Aunt Emma, who is a British national and thus outside the reach of American authorities. He uses the wife and in-laws of his friend Brad Bodnick, who have European passports, to smuggle the cash into Switzerland.
Donnie gets into a public brawl with Brad, and, while Donnie escapes, Brad is arrested. Brad does not say a word about Donnie or Jordan to the police. Jordan learns from his private investigator that the FBI is wiretapping his phones. Fearing for his son, Jordan's father advises him to leave Stratton Oakmont and lie low while Jordan's lawyer negotiates a deal to keep him out of prison. Jordan, however, cannot bear to quit and talks himself into staying in the middle of his farewell speech. Jordan, Donnie, and their wives are on a yacht trip to Italy when they learn that Aunt Emma has died of a heart attack. Jordan decides to travel to Switzerland immediately to settle the bank account. To bypass border controls, he orders his yacht captain to sail to Monaco, but the ship is capsized in a storm. After their rescue, the plane sent to take them to Geneva is destroyed when a seagull flies into the engine. Jordan takes this as a sign from God and decides to sober up.
Two years later, the FBI arrests Jordan because Saurel, arrested in Florida on an unrelated charge, has informed the FBI on Jordan. Since the evidence against him is overwhelming, Jordan agrees to gather evidence on his colleagues in exchange for leniency. Now fed up with Jordan's lifestyle, Naomi tells Jordan she is divorcing him and wants full custody of their children. Infuriated, Jordan hits Naomi twice, insults her as a "[[cunt]]" and tries to run off with his daughter Skylar in his car, but he ends up crashing in the driveway. The next morning, Jordan wears a wire to work but slips a note to Donnie warning him. Donnie keeps the note and rats out Jordan to the FBI. Jordan is arrested for breaching his co-operation deal. The FBI raids and shuts down Stratton Oakmont. Despite his breach, Jordan receives a reduced sentence for his testimony and serves three years in a minimum security prison. After his release, Jordan makes a living hosting seminars on sales technique.
==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] as [[Jordan Belfort]] * [[Jonah Hill]] as Donnie Azoff * [[Margot Robbie]] as Naomi Lapaglia * [[Kyle Chandler]] as Patrick Denham * [[Rob Reiner]] as Max Belfort * [[Jon Bernthal]] as Brad Bodnick * [[Matthew McConaughey]] as Mark Hanna * [[Jon Favreau]] as Manny Riskin * [[Jean Dujardin]] as Jean-Jacques Saurel * [[Joanna Lumley]] as Aunt Emma * [[Cristin Milioti]] as Teresa Petrillo * [[Christine Ebersole]] as Leah Belfort * [[Shea Whigham]] as Captain Ted Beecham * [[Katarina Čas]] as Chantalle Bodnick * [[P. J. Byrne]] as Nicky Koskoff * [[Kenneth Choi]] as Chester Ming * [[Brian Sacca]] as Robbie Feinberg * [[Henry Zebrowski]] as Alden Kupferberg * [[Ethan Suplee]] as Toby Welch * [[Jake Hoffman]] as [[Steve Madden]] * [[Mackenzie Meehan]] as Hildy Azoff * [[Bo Dietl]] as himself * [[Jordan Belfort]] as Auckland Straight Line Host {{div col end}}
==Production== [[File:Leonardo DiCaprio 2014.jpg|thumb|upright|Leonardo DiCaprio attending the film's London premiere in January 2014]]
===Development=== In 2007, [[Leonardo DiCaprio]]/[[Warner Bros.]] won a bidding war against [[Brad Pitt]]/[[Paramount Pictures]] for the rights to Jordan Belfort's memoir ''The Wolf of Wall Street'', and Martin Scorsese was considered to direct the film.<ref>{{cite news|author=Pamela McClintock |url=https://variety.com/2007/film/news/scorsese-dicaprio-cry-wolf-1117961782/ |title=Scorsese, DiCaprio cry ‘Wolf’ |newspaper=Variety |date=2007-03-25 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref><ref name="Hollywood Reporter" /> During pre-production, Scorsese worked on the film's script before working on ''[[Shutter Island (film)|Shutter Island]]''. He describes having "wasted five months of [his] life" without getting a [[Green-light|green light]] on production dates by the Warner Bros. studio.<ref>{{cite web |first=Jerry |last=Saravia |title=Raging Bull of Cinema Part II|url=http://jerrysaravia.blogspot.com/2011/08/raging-of-bull-of-cinema-part-2.html |date=June 5, 2013 |accessdate=June 22, 2013}}</ref> Jordan Belfort made $1 million on the movie rights.<ref>{{cite web |author=Charlie Gasparino |url=http://www.foxbusiness.com/2013/03/12/wolf-wall-street-gets-1m-pay-day-for-movie-rights/ |title='Wolf of Wall Street' Gets $1M Pay Day for Movie Rights |publisher=Fox Business |date=2013-03-12 |accessdate=2014-02-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140217034106/http://www.foxbusiness.com/2013/03/12/wolf-wall-street-gets-1m-pay-day-for-movie-rights/ |archivedate=February 17, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In 2010, Warner Bros. had offered [[Ridley Scott]] to direct the film, with Leonardo DiCaprio playing the male lead,<ref>{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/07/ridley-scott-eyeing-reteam-with-leo-dicaprio-on-the-wolf-of-wall-street/ |title=Ridley Scott Eyeing Reteam With Leo DiCaprio On 'The Wolf Of Wall Street' |publisher=Deadline.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> but the studio eventually dumped the project.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/05/cannes-red-granite-acquires-leonardo-dicaprio-pic-the-wolf-of-wall-street/ |title=Cannes: Red Granite Acquires Leonardo DiCaprio Pic 'The Wolf Of Wall Street' |publisher=Deadline.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref>
In 2012, a green light was given by the [[Independent film|independent company]] [[Red Granite Pictures]] allowing no restrictions to the content development. Scorsese knew that there were no limits to the content that he would produce and therefore came back on board, resulting in an [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system#MPAA film ratings|R rating]].<ref>{{cite web|work=[[Vulture (blog)|Vulture]]|date=2013-08-25|title=Leonardo DiCaprio and Martin Scorsese Explore the Funny Side of Financial Depravity in The Wolf of Wall Street|url=http://www.vulture.com/2013/08/dicaprio-scorsese-wolf-of-wall-street.html|first=Mary Kaye|last=Schilling}}</ref> Red Granite Pictures also asked [[Paramount Pictures]] to distribute the film;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/01/oscars-qa-wolf-of-wall-street-producer-emma-tillinger-koskoff-on-sexy-scary-infuriating-pic/ |title=OSCARS Q&A: 'Wolf Of Wall Street' Producer Emma Tillinger Koskoff On 'Sexy, Scary, Infuriating' Pic |publisher=Deadline.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> [[Paramount Pictures]] agreed to distribute the film in North America and Japan, but passed on the rest of the international market.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/23/business/media/strong-profit-margin-at-paramount-pictures-underlines-a-hollywood-shift.html?pagewanted=all|title=Strong Profit Margin at Paramount Pictures Underlines a Hollywood Shift|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2012-02-12|first1=Michael|last1=Cieply|first2=Brooks|last2=Barnes}}</ref>
The FBI has issued subpoenas to several past and present employees of Red Granite Pictures in regards to allegations that US$155 million was diverted from the Malaysian wealth fund [[1MDB]] to help finance ''The Wolf of Wall Street''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/malaysias-1mdb-the-secret-money-behind-the-wolf-of-wall-street-1459531987|title=The Secret Money Behind 'The Wolf of Wall Street'|first1=Bradley|last1=Hope|first2=John R. Emshwiller And Ben|last2=Fritz|date=1 April 2016|newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/malaysia-s-1mdb-financed/2659892.html|title=Malaysia's 1MDB refutes report that it financed 'Wolf of Wall Street': Statement |website=Channelnewsasia.com|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theedgemarkets.com/my/article/fbi-probes-1mdb-red-granite-us155m-financing-claim-wsj|title=FBI probes 1MDB-Red Granite US$155m financing claim |website=Theedgemarkets.com|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inquisitr.com/2954717/the-wolf-of-wall-street-financial-scandal-in-malaysia/|title='The Wolf of Wall Street' Financed By Wolf of Malaysia? |website=Inquistr.com|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref> This relates to the [[1Malaysia Development Berhad scandal]]. A civil lawsuit initiated by the U.S. Department of Justice has sought to claim "any rights to profits, royalties and distribution proceeds" from ''The Wolf of Wall Street''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/07/20/news/wolf-of-wall-street-malaysia-1mdb/index.html|title=Feds want 'Wolf of Wall Street' profits as part of $3.5 billion fraud allegations|last=Pagliery|first=Jose|date=2016-07-20|website=CNNMoney|access-date=2016-07-21}}</ref> To settle the civil lawsuit, Red Granite Pictures has agreed to pay US$60 million to the U.S. government.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-malaysia-scandal-redgranite/the-wolf-of-wall-street-producers-to-pay-60-million-to-u-s-in-lawsuit-settlement-idUSKCN1GJ0FH|title='The Wolf of Wall Street' producers to pay $60 million to U.S. in...|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
In the film, most of the real-life characters' names have been changed from Belfort's original memoir. Donnie Azoff is based on [[Danny Porush]]. The name was changed after Porush threatened to sue the filmmakers. Porush maintains that much of the film was fictional and that Donnie Azoff was not in fact an accurate depiction of him.<ref name=NYDailyNews>{{cite news |title=Real 'Wolf of Wall Street' exec's son slams movie's 'inaccurate' characterization of his father|newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|location=New York|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/real-wolf-wall-street-exec-son-slams-movie-inaccurate-characterization-father-article-1.1552963|date= December 19, 2013|accessdate= 1 March 2014}}</ref><ref name=Time>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|author=Dockterman, Eliana|title=The Wolf of Wall Street: The True Story|url=http://entertainment.time.com/2013/12/26/wolf-wall-street-true-story/|date= December 26, 2013|accessdate= 1 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=I saw him morph from nice guy into showy narcissist': Ex wife of former Wolf of Wall St. reveals what it was like to be married to Danny Porush|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2521346/Ex-wife-Wolf-Wall-St-reveals-like-married-Danny-Porush.html|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|date= 10 December 2013|accessdate= 1 March 2014|location=London}}</ref> The FBI agent known as Patrick Denham is the stand-in for real-life Gregory Coleman,<ref name="Chandler">{{cite web | last = Napier | first = Jim |title=Kyle Chandler Joins Martin Scorsese's THE WOLF OF WALL STREET |url=http://geektyrant.com/news/2012/5/10/kyle-chandler-joins-martin-scorseses-the-wolf-of-wall-street.html |work=Geektyrant.com |publisher=Geektyrant Industries LLC |accessdate=August 11, 2012}}</ref> and lawyer Manny Riskin is based on [[Ira Sorkin]].<ref name="Sorkin">{{cite web |author=Paur, Joey |title=Jon Favreau Joins Martin Scorsese's THE WOLF OF WALL STREET |url=http://geektyrant.com/news/2012/7/25/jon-favreau-joins-martin-scorseses-the-wolf-of-wall-street.html |work=Geektyrant.com |publisher=Geektyrant Industries LLC |accessdate=August 11, 2012}}</ref> Belfort's first wife Denise Lombardo is renamed Teresa Petrillo, while second wife Nadine Caridi became Naomi Lapaglia on-screen. In contrast, Mark Hanna's name remains the same as the LF Rothschild stockbroker who, like Belfort, was convicted of fraud and served time in prison.<ref name=USAToday>{{cite news|title=Excerpt of 'The Wolf of Wall Street'|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/books/2007-10-12-wolf-wall-street-excerpt_n.htm|newspaper=USA Today|accessdate=21 December 2013|date=October 12, 2007}}</ref><ref name=YouTube>{{cite web|last=Dungan|first=Isabelle|title=The Real Wolf of Wall Street|url=//www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jwa9rGawGsA&feature=youtube_gdata|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=21 December 2013}}</ref> Belfort's parents Max and Leah Belfort's names remained the same for the film.<ref>{{cite web|last=Peyser|first=Andrea|title=‘Wolf of Wall Street’ can’t shake Queens roots|url=https://nypost.com/2013/12/09/wolf-of-wall-street-cant-shake-queens-roots/|work=nypost.com|accessdate=December 13, 2013}}</ref> The role of Aunt Emma was initially offered to [[Julie Andrews]], who refused it as she was recovering from an ankle injury, and she was replaced by [[Joanna Lumley]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/english/hollywood/news-interviews/Ankle-injury-made-Julie-Andrews-miss-Wolf-Of-Wall-Street/articleshow/33491983.cms? | title=Ankle injury made Julie Andrews miss Wolf Of Wall Street | work=The Times of India | accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref>
In January 2014, [[Jonah Hill]] revealed in an interview with [[Howard Stern]] that he made only $60,000 on the film (the lowest possible [[SAG-AFTRA]] rate for his amount of work), while his co-star Leonardo DiCaprio (who also produced) received $10 million. Hill didn't care about his settlement though, and wanted to play Donnie Azoff so badly that he was willing to do whatever it took to get the part as it was his dream to be in a Scorsese film.<ref>{{cite web|author=Matt Joseph |url=http://wegotthiscovered.com/movies/jonah-hill-60000-wolf-wall-street/ |title=Jonah Hill Made $60,000 On The Wolf Of Wall Street |publisher=Wegotthiscovered.com |date=2014-01-22 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2014/01/22/jonah-hill-made-just-60k-for-wolf-of-wall-street/4774601/ |title=Jonah Hill made just $60K for 'Wolf of Wall Street' |newspaper=USA Today |date=2014-01-22 |accessdate=2014-02-12 |first1=Arienne |last1=Thompson}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jonah-hill-says-he-was-673215 |title=Jonah Hill Says He Was Paid $60K for 'The Wolf of Wall Street' (Audio) |newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter |date=2014-01-22 |accessdate=2014-02-12 |first=Hilary |last=Lewis}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Cavan Sieczkowski |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/01/22/jonah-hill-paid-60000-wolf_n_4643520.html?ncid=edlinkusaolp00000003 |title=Jonah Hill Paid Paltry $60,000 For 'Wolf Of Wall Street' |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date=2014-01-22 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref>
===Filming=== [[Principal photography|Filming]] began on August 8, 2012, in New York.<ref>{{cite web |first=David |last=Berov |title=Screenwriter Terence Winter Talks The Wolf Of Wall Street |url=http://afterthecut.com/2012/08/07/screenwriter-terence-winter-talks-the-wolf-of-wall-street |publisher=AfterTheCut.com |date=August 7, 2012 |accessdate=August 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140906160540/http://afterthecut.com/2012/08/07/screenwriter-terence-winter-talks-the-wolf-of-wall-street/ |archivedate=September 6, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> [[Jonah Hill]] announced that his first day of shooting was September 4, 2012.<ref>{{cite web |first=Jonah |last=Hill |title=Jonah Hill announces completion of first day of shooting Wolf of Wall Street |url=https://twitter.com/JonahHill/status/243109759887220736 |date=September 4, 2012 |accessdate=September 4, 2012}}</ref> Filming also took place in [[Closter, New Jersey]]<ref>{{cite web |first=Stephanie |last=Simone |title=Leo and crew converge on Closter for latest Martin Scorsese film |url=http://www.northjersey.com/community/169581156_Leo_and_crew_converge_on_Closter_for_latest_Martin_Scorsese_film.html |work=NorthJersey.com |date=September 13, 2012 |accessdate=September 13, 2012}}</ref> and [[Harrison, New York]]. In January 2013, additional scenes were shot at a set built in an abandoned office building in [[Ardsley, New York]]. Scenes at the beach house were filmed in [[Sands Point, New York]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.movieloci.com/2477-The-Wolf-of-Wall-Street?snapshot=29334 |title=The Wolf of Wall Street | Jordan's House on the beach |publisher=MovieLoci.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref>
Scorsese's longtime editor [[Thelma Schoonmaker]] stated that the film would be shot [[Digital cinematography|digitally]] instead of on [[film stock|film]].<ref name="Empire">{{cite web |first=Phil |last=de Semlyen |title=Scorsese Goes Digital, Abandons Film |url=http://www.empireonline.com/news/story.asp?NID=34396 |publisher=EmpireOnline.com |date=June 27, 2012 |accessdate=August 21, 2012}}</ref> Scorsese had been a proponent of shooting on film but decided to shoot ''[[Hugo (film)|Hugo]]'' digitally because it was being photographed in [[3D film|3D]]; however, ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' was originally planned to be shot digitally despite being filmed in 2D.<ref name="American Cinematographer Magazine">{{cite web |first=Michael |last=Goldman |title=Rodrigo Prieto, ASC, AMC and Martin Scorsese discuss their approach to The Wolf of Wall Street, the true story of a stockbrocker run amok. |url=http://www.theasc.com/ac_magazine/December2013/TheWolfofWallStreet/page1.php |publisher=theasc.com |date=December 2013 |accessdate=December 24, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223235423/http://www.theasc.com/ac_magazine/December2013/TheWolfofWallStreet/page1.php |archivedate=February 23, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Schoonmaker expressed her disappointment with the decision: "It would appear that we've lost the [[Digital versus film photography|battle]]. I think Marty just feels it's unfortunately over, and there's been no bigger champion of film than him."<ref name="Empire" /> After extensive comparison tests during pre-production, eventually the majority of the film was shot on film stock while scenes that used [[Chroma key|green screen]] effects or low light were shot with the digital [[Arri Alexa]].<ref name="American Cinematographer Magazine"/> The film contains 400–450 [[VFX]] shots.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bennett|first=Neil|title=Interview: The Wolf of Wall Street's VFX producer|url=http://www.digitalartsonline.co.uk/features/motion-graphics/interview-wolf-of-wall-streets-vfx-producer/|publisher=Digitalartsonline.co.uk|accessdate=December 17, 2013|date=September 20, 2013}}</ref>
===Use of animals=== ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' uses animals including a chimpanzee, a lion, a snake, a fish, and dogs.<ref name="tadeo">{{cite news | last=Tadeo | first=Maria | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/chimpanzee-dressed-in-a-suit-rollerskating-through-prostitutes-and-dwarves-in-wolf-of-wall-street-prompts-boycott-calls-9008405.html | title=Chimpanzee dressed in a suit roller-skating through prostitutes and dwarves in Wolf of Wall Street prompts boycott calls | work=[[The Independent]] | date=December 16, 2013 | accessdate=January 16, 2014 | location=London}}</ref> The chimpanzee and the lion were provided by the Big Cat Habitat wildlife sanctuary in [[Sarasota County, Florida]]. The four-year-old chimpanzee Chance spent time with actor Leonardo DiCaprio and learned to roller skate over the course of three weeks. The sanctuary also provided a lion named Handsome because the film's trading company used a lion for its symbol.<ref>{{cite news | last=Cummings | first=Ian | url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/article/20131226/article/131229775 | title=Sarasota chimp and lion have roles in 'Wolf of Wall Street' | work=[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]] | date=December 26, 2013 | accessdate=January 16, 2014 }}</ref> [[Danny Porush]], [[Jordan Belfort]]'s real-life partner, denied that there were any animals in the office, although he admitted to eating an employee's goldfish.<ref name="child">{{cite news | last=Child | first=Ben | url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2013/dec/16/martin-scorsese-wolf-of-wall-street-animal-welfare | title=Scorsese's The Wolf of Wall Street: animal rights group calls for boycott | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=December 16, 2013 | accessdate=January 16, 2014 }}</ref>
In December 2013, before the film's premiere, the organization [[Friends of Animals]] criticized the use of the chimpanzee and organized a boycott of the film. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' reported, "Friends of Animals thinks the chimp ... suffered irreversible psychological damage after being forced to act."<ref name="variety-boycott">{{cite journal | last=Khatchatourian | first=Maane | url= https://variety.com/2013/film/news/wolf-of-wall-street-boycot-1200953311/ | title= Animal Rights Group Boycotting 'Wolf of Wall Street' | journal= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date= December 13, 2013 | accessdate=January 16, 2014 }}</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'' said, "Criticism of ''The Wolf of Wall Street'''s use of a chimpanzee arrives as Hollywood comes under ever-increasing scrutiny for its employment of animals on screen," referring to a November 2013 report in ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' that was critical of the [[American Humane Association]]'s treatment of animals in films.<ref name="child" /> [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]] also launched a campaign to highlight mistreatment of ape "actors" and to petition for DiCaprio not to work with great apes.<ref>{{cite news| last=Kenneally | first=Tim | url=http://www.thewrap.com/leonardo-dicaprio-wolf-of-wall-street-peta-animal-rights | title=Leonardo DiCaprio Slammed by PETA Over ‘Wolf of Wall Street’ Monkey Business | work=The Wrap | publisher=The Wrap News, Inc. | date=December 16, 2013 | accessdate=January 16, 2014}}</ref>
==Release== {{multiple image <!-- Essential parameters --> | align = right | direction = vertical | footer = [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] and [[Martin Scorsese]] in Paris at the film's French premiere, December 2013. | width = <!-- Image 1 --> | image1 = Leonardo DiCaprio avp 2013 2.jpg | width1 = 173 | alt1 = | caption1 =
<!-- Image 2 --> | image2 = Martin Scorsese avp 2013.jpg | width2 = 171 | alt2 = | caption2 = }} ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' premiered at the [[Ziegfeld Theatre (1969)|Ziegfeld Theatre]] in New York City on December 17, 2013,<ref>{{cite news|last=Morfoot|first=Addie|title=Terence Winter: Leo ‘Brave Enough’ for Candle Scene in ‘Wolf of Wall Street’|url=https://variety.com/2013/scene/news/terence-winter-leo-brave-enough-for-candle-scene-in-wolf-of-wall-street-1200973258/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=March 26, 2014|date=December 18, 2013}}</ref> followed by a wide release on December 25, 2013. It was previously slated to be released on November 15, 2013, but the date was pushed back after film cuts were made to reduce the run time.<ref>{{cite news |first=Pamela |last=McClintock |title=Wolf of Wall Street Avoids NC-17 After Sex Cuts |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/wolf-wall-street-avoids-nc-660653 |work=HollywoodReporter.com |date=November 27, 2013 |accessdate=December 13, 2013}}</ref> On October 22, 2013, it was reported that the film was set for a Christmas 2013 release.<ref>{{cite web |first=Brad |last=Brevet |title=Scorsese's 'Wolf of Wall Street' Will Open on Christmas Day |url=http://www.ropeofsilicon.com/scorseses-wolf-wall-street-will-open-christmas-day/ |work=Ropeofsilicon.com |date=October 22, 2013 |accessdate=October 22, 2013}}</ref> Paramount officially confirmed the Christmas Day 2013 release date on October 29, 2013, with a running time of 165 minutes.<ref name="Hollywood Reporter">{{cite news|first=Pamela|last=McClintock|title=It's Official: Martin Scorsese's 'Wolf of Wall Street' Gets Holiday Release|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/martin-scorseses-wolf-wall-street-651367|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=28 October 2013|accessdate=29 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Jeff |last=Labrecque |title=Scorsese's 'Wolf of Wall Street' Will Open on Christmas Day |url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/10/29/wolf-of-wall-street-release-date-christmas/ |work=ew.com |date=October 29, 2013 |accessdate=October 29, 2013}}</ref> On November 25, 2013, the length was announced to be 179 minutes.<ref name="collider">{{cite web|date=25 November 2013|last=Goldberg|first=Matt|url=http://collider.com/the-wolf-of-wall-street-runtime/|title=THE WOLF OF WALL STREET Could Be Martin Scorsese’s Longest Film Yet at 179 Minutes; 3 New Posters Released|accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref> It was officially rated R for "sequences of strong sexual content, graphic nudity, drug use and language throughout, and for some violence".<ref name=wolf>{{cite web|url=//www.youtube.com/watch?v=iszwuX1AK6A|title=The Wolf of Wall Street Official Trailer|date=16 June 2013|work=[[Paramount Pictures]]|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=16 June 2013}}</ref> Scorsese had to edit sexual content and nudity to avoid an [[NC-17]] rating.<ref>{{cite web | last = Feldberg | first = Isaac |title= The Wolf Of Wall Street Was Nearly Rated NC-17 For Nudity And Sex |url=http://wegotthiscovered.com/movies/wolf-wall-street-nearly-rated-nc17-check-out-new-spot/ |work=WeGotThisCovered.com |publisher=We Got This Covered |date=November 28, 2013 |accessdate=November 28, 2013}}</ref> By different counts, the film contains between 506 and 569 uses of the word "fuck",<ref name="slate-fuck">{{cite web | date = January 7, 2014 | author = Forrest Wickman | url = http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2014/01/07/wolf_of_wall_street_sets_f_word_record_we_counted_every_last_f_bomb_in_the.html | title = Is Wolf of Wall Street Really the Sweariest Movie of All Time? A Slate Investigation |work = [[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] }}</ref><ref name="screenit">{{cite web |url= http://www.screenitplus.com/members/the_wolf_of_wall_street_Full_Content_Review.cfm | title= The Wolf Of Wall Street Breaks Full Content Review |publisher=screenit.com |date=2013-12-25 |accessdate=2013-12-25}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> and currently holds the record for the [[List of films that most frequently use the word "fuck"|most uses of the word in a mainstream non-documentary film]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wegotthiscovered.com/movies/wolf-wall-street-breaks-record-profanity-movie/ |title=The Wolf Of Wall Street Breaks The Record For Most Profanity In A Movie |publisher=wegotthiscovered.com |date=2013-12-30 |accessdate=2013-12-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.junkiemonkeys.com/the-wolf-of-wall-street-breaks-profanity-record/ |title=The Wolf of Wall Street Breaks Profanity Record |publisher=junkiemonkeys.com |date=2013-12-29 |accessdate=2013-12-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | date = January 12, 2014 | author = Adam Holz | url = http://www.pluggedin.ca/movies/intheaters/wolf-of-wall-street.aspx | title = Review: The Wolf of Wall Street | work = [[Plugged In]] | quote = a handful more than 525 are f-words }}</ref>
The film is banned in [[Malaysia]], [[Nepal]], [[Zimbabwe]], and [[Kenya]] because of its scenes depicting sex, drugs and excessive use of swear words, and additional scenes have been cut in the versions playing in [[India]]. In [[Singapore]], after cuts were made to an orgy scene as well as some religiously profane or denigrating language, the film was passed R21.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moviethatmatters.com/gay-orgy-gone-wolf-wall-street-censored-banned-overseas/ |title=Gay Orgy, Gone! ‘Wolf of Wall Street’ Censored, Banned Overseas |website=MovieThatMatters |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140130091628/http://www.moviethatmatters.com/gay-orgy-gone-wolf-wall-street-censored-banned-overseas/ |archivedate=January 30, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Martin Scorsese’s ‘The Wolf of Wall Street’ banned in Kenya | date = January 16, 2014 | author = Capital lifestyle | url = http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/lifestyle/2014/01/16/martin-scorseses-the-wolf-of-wall-street-banned-in-kenya/ }}</ref>
The film marks a change in film history when Paramount became the first major studio to distribute movies to theaters in digital format, eliminating 35mm film entirely. ''[[Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues]]'' was the last Paramount production to include a [[35mm format|35mm film]] version, while ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' was the first major movie distributed entirely digitally.<ref name="geuss">{{cite web |url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2014/01/anchorman-2-was-paramounts-final-release-on-35mm-film/ |title=Anchorman 2 was Paramount’s final release on 35mm film |work=Ars Technica (via Los Angeles Times) |author=Megan Geuss |date=January 18, 2014 |accessdate=January 20, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Verrier |first=Richard |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-paramount-digital-20140117,0,5245137.story |title=End of film: Paramount first studio to stop distributing film prints |publisher=latimes.com |date=2014-01-17 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref>
===Box office=== ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' grossed $116.9 million in North America and $275.1 million internationally, for a total gross of $392 million,<ref name="mojo" /> making it Scorsese's highest-grossing film worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/wolf-wall-street-is-martin-679314|title=Box-Office Milestone: 'Wolf of Wall Street' Becomes Martin Scorsese's Top-Grossing Film|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]}}</ref> In North America, the film opened at number five in its first weekend, with $18.4 million in 3,387 theaters, behind ''[[The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug]]'', ''[[Frozen (2013 film)|Frozen]]'', ''[[Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues]]'', and ''[[American Hustle]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=2013&wknd=52&p=.htm |title=Weekend Box Office Results for December 27–29, 2013 |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=2014-02-19}}</ref> In Australia, it is the highest grossing R-rated film, earning $12.96 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/the-wolf-of-wall-street-sets-australian-record-for-an-rrated-film-20140206-3234g.html|title=The Wolf of Wall Street sets Australian record for an R-rated film|website=Smh.com.au}}</ref>
===File sharing=== According to [[copyright infringement]] tracking site Excipio, the film was the most illegally downloaded film of 2014, as it was shared over 30 million times via torrent sites.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://variety.com/2014/digital/news/top-20-most-pirated-movies-of-2014-led-by-wolf-of-wall-street-frozen-gravity-1201388403/ | title = Top 20 Most Pirated Movies of 2014 Led by 'Wolf of Wall Street,' 'Frozen,' 'Gravity' | author = Todd Spangler | publisher = ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' | date = December 28, 2014 | accessdate = February 21, 2015}}</ref>
===Home media=== ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' was released on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray]] on March 25, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/news/?id=13282 |title=The Wolf of Wall Street Blu-ray |publisher=Blu-ray.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-19}}</ref> On January 27, 2014, it was revealed that a four-hour [[director's cut]] would be attached to the home release.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Ann|title=The Wolf of Wall Street DVD will be 4 hours long with more sex and swearing|url=http://metro.co.uk/2014/01/28/the-wolf-of-wall-street-dvd-will-be-4-hours-long-with-more-sex-and-swearing-4280723/|work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|accessdate=February 20, 2014|date=January 28, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Desborough|first=James|title=EXCLUSIVE: Wolf of Wall Street DVD will be an HOUR longer – with even more F-bombs and longer sex scenes|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2546958/EXCLUSIVE-Wolf-Wall-Street-DVD-HOUR-longer-F-bombs-longer-sex-scenes.html|work=[[Mail Online]]|accessdate=February 20, 2014|date=January 27, 2014|location=London}}</ref> It was later revealed by [[Paramount Pictures]] and [[Red Granite Pictures]] that the home release would feature only the theatrical release.<ref>{{cite web|last=Goldberg|first=Matt|title=THE WOLF OF WALL STREET Blu-ray/DVD May Include an Extended Cut with an Extra Hour of Sex and Swearing [UPDATED]|url=http://collider.com/the-wolf-of-wall-street-extended-cut-4-hours/|publisher=Collider|accessdate=February 20, 2014|date=January 29, 2014}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Critical response=== ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' received positive reviews, with critics praising DiCaprio and Hill's performances, Scorsese's direction, and Winter's screenplay. On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film holds an approval rating of 78% based on 267 reviews, with an average rating of 7.8/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Funny, self-referential, and irreverent to a fault, ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' finds Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio at their most infectiously dynamic."<ref name="The Wolf of Wall Street 2013">{{cite web | url = https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_wolf_of_wall_street_2013/ | title = The Wolf of Wall Street (2013) | publisher = [[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate = September 26, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a weighted average score of 75 out of 100, based on 47 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.metacritic.com/movie/the-wolf-of-wall-street |title=The Wolf of Wall Street reviews |publisher= [[Metacritic]] |accessdate= December 25, 2013}}</ref>
[[Peter Travers]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine named ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' as the third best film of 2013, behind ''[[12 Years a Slave (film)|12 Years a Slave]]'' and ''[[Gravity (film)|Gravity]]'' at numbers one and two, respectively. The movie was chosen as one of the top ten films of the year by the [[American Film Institute]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/about/releases/2013/AFI_Awards_2013_honorees.aspx|title=10 Outstanding Motion Pictures and Television Programs Inducted into the AFI Almanac of the Art Form|date=December 9, 2013|work=[[American Film Institute]]|accessdate=January 16, 2014}}</ref> [[Mick LaSalle]] of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' said "it is the best and most enjoyable American film to be released this year."<ref>{{cite news|author=Mick LaSalle |url=http://www.sfgate.com/movies/article/Wolf-of-Wall-Street-review-Scorsese-right-on-5091280.php |title='Wolf of Wall Street' review: Scorsese right on the money |publisher=SFGate |date=2013-12-24 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> ''[[The Chicago Sun-Times]]'''s [[Richard Roeper]] gave the film a "B+" score, saying the film was "good, not great Scorsese".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.richardroeper.com/reviews/thewolfofwallstreet.aspx|title=The Wolf of Wall Street |website=RichardRoeper.com|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref>
[[Dana Stevens (critic)|Dana Stevens]], a member of the [[New York Film Critics Circle]], wrote that the movie did not work for her after labeling the film "Epic in size, claustrophobically narrow in scope."<ref>{{cite web|last=Stevens|first=Dana|title=The Wolf of Wall Street|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/movies/2013/12/scorsese_s_wolf_of_wall_street_starring_leonardo_dicaprio_reviewed.html|work=Slate|accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref> According to Marshall Fine of ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' the story "wants us to be interested in characters who are dull people to start with, made duller by their delusions of being interesting because they are high".<ref name="huffpost">{{cite news|url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/marshall-fine/movie-review-ithe-wolf-of_b_4489053.html |title=Movie Review: The Wolf of Wall Street|last=Fine|first=Marshall|date=December 22, 2013|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=January 16, 2014}}</ref> Some critics viewed the movie as an irresponsible glorification rather than a satirical takedown. DiCaprio responded that in his opinion the film does not glorify the excessive lifestyle it depicts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moviethatmatters.com/leonardo-dicaprio-wolf-wall-street-critics-missed-boat-entirely/|title=Leonardo DiCaprio Defends 'Wolf of Wall Street' Amid Controversy|date=December 31, 2013|work=MovieThatMatters.com|accessdate=16 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncronline.org/blogs/just-catholic/culture-prosperity/|title=The 'culture of prosperity'|last=Zagano|first=Phyllis|date=1 January 2014|work=National Catholic Reporter|accessdate=16 January 2014}}</ref>
In 2016, the film was ranked #78 on the [[BBC's 100 Greatest Films of the 21st Century]] list.<ref>{{cite web|title=The 21st Century’s 100 greatest films|url=http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20160819-the-21st-centurys-100-greatest-films|website=[[BBC]]|date=23 August 2016|accessdate=7 May 2017}}</ref> In June 2017, [[Richard Brody]] of ''[[The New Yorker]]'' named ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' as the 2nd best film of the 21st century so far, behind [[Jean-Luc Godard]]'s ''[[In Praise of Love (film)|In Praise of Love]]'' (2001).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Brody|first1=Richard|authorlink=Richard Brody|title=My Twenty-Five Best Films of the Century So Far|url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/richard-brody/my-twenty-five-best-films-of-the-century-so-far|website=[[The New Yorker]]|publisher=[[Condé Nast]]|accessdate=25 October 2017|date=12 June 2017}}</ref>
===Top ten lists=== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' was listed on many critics' top ten lists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/feature/film-critic-top-10-lists-best-movies-of-2013|title=2013 Film Critic Top Ten Lists|website=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive|CBS Interactive Inc.]]|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref> * 1st – Richard Brody, ''[[The New Yorker]]'' (tied with ''[[To the Wonder]]'') * 1st – Stephen Schaefer, ''[[Boston Herald]]'' * 2nd – [[Wesley Morris]], ''[[Grantland]]'' * 2nd – [[Mick LaSalle]], ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' * 2nd – Ben Kenigsberg, ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' * 3rd – [[James Berardinelli]], ''Reelviews'' * 3rd – ''[[MTV]]'' * 3rd – [[Glenn Kenny]], ''[[RogerEbert.com]]'' * 3rd – [[Peter Travers]], ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' * 4th – Scott Feinberg, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' * 4th – [[Drew McWeeny]], ''[[HitFix]]'' * 4th – ''[[Yahoo! Movies]]'' * 4th – [[Christopher Orr (film critic)|Christopher Orr]], ''[[The Atlantic]]'' * 4th – Barbara Vancheri, ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'' * 5th – [[Caryn James]], ''[[Indiewire]]''<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2013/12/best-films-of-2013-216330/|title=BEST FILMS OF 2013|last=James|first=Caryn|date=2013-12-20|work=IndieWire|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en-US}}</ref> * 5th – [[Stephen Holden]], ''[[The New York Times]]'' * 5th – [[Rex Reed]], ''[[The New York Observer]]'' * 5th – Katey Rich, ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' * 5th – David Chen, ''[[/Film]]'' * 6th – ''[[TV Guide]]'' * 7th – [[Matt Zoller Seitz]], ''RogerEbert.com'' * 7th – ''[[Film School Rejects]]'' * 7th – [[Todd McCarthy]], ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' * 7th – Scott Tobias, ''[[The Dissolve]]'' * 7th – Scott Mantz, ''[[Access Hollywood]]'' * 7th – Mark Mohan, ''[[The Oregonian]]'' * 7th – Sam Adams, ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' * 8th – [[Nathan Rabin]], ''[[The Dissolve]]'' * 8th – Bill Goodykoontz, ''[[Arizona Republic]]'' * 8th – Randy Myers, ''[[San Jose Mercury News]]'' * 9th – Joe Neumaier, ''[[New York Daily News]]'' * 10th – Andrew O'Hehir, ''[[Salon.com]]'' * 10th – Jessica Kiang and Katie Walsh, ''[[Indiewire]]'' * 10th – [[A.O. Scott]], ''[[The New York Times]]'' * 10th – Rene Rodriguez, ''[[Miami Herald]]'' * 10th – Marjorie Baumgarten, ''[[Austin Chronicle]]'' * 10th – Keith Uhlich, ''[[Time Out New York]]'' * Top 10 (listed alphabetically, not ranked) – James Verniere, ''[[Boston Herald]]'' * Top 10 (listed alphabetically, not ranked) – Stephen Whitty, ''[[The Star-Ledger]]'' * Top 10 (ranked alphabetically) – [[Joe Williams (film critic)|Joe Williams]], ''[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]'' {{div col end}}
===Audience response=== <!-- DO NOT ADD IMDB or Rotten Tomatoes or other web polls as they are not reliable sources. -->The film received a "C" rating from audiences surveyed by [[CinemaScore]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/3-Obvious-Reasons-Why-Audiences-Hate-Wolf-Wall-Street-40873.html |title=3 Obvious Reasons Why Audiences Hate The Wolf Of Wall Street |publisher=CinemaBlend.com |date=2013-12-27 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> a rating lower than anything else in theaters the opening week of the film.<ref name="vf" /> The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' argues that the film attracted conservative viewers by depicting a more moral tone in its marketing than the film itself depicted.<ref>{{cite news | author = Steven Zeitchik | date = December 26, 2013 |url= http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-wolf-of-wall-street-scorsese-sex-drugs-20131226,0,2452467.story |title='The Wolf of Wall Street:' Is it too polarizing for the mainstream? (2013) |work= [[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=December 28, 2013}}</ref>
Christina McDowell, daughter of Tom Prousalis, who worked closely with the real-life Belfort at Stratton Oakmont, wrote an [[open letter]] addressing Scorsese, DiCaprio, and Belfort himself, criticizing the film for insufficiently portraying the victims of the financial crimes created by Stratton Oakmont, for disregarding the damage that was done to her family as a result, and for giving celebrity to persons (Belfort and his partners, including her father) who do not deserve it.<ref name="laweekly">{{cite web | date = December 26, 2013 | author = Christina McDowell | url = http://blogs.laweekly.com/informer/2013/12/wolf_of_wall_street_prousalis.php?page=2 | title = An Open Letter to the Makers of The Wolf of Wall Street, and the Wolf Himself | work = [[LA Weekly]] }}</ref>
Steven Perlberg of ''[[Business Insider]]'' saw an [[screener (promotional)|advance screening]] of the film at a [[Regal Entertainment Group|Regal Cinemas]] near the [[Goldman Sachs]] building, with an audience of financial workers. Perlberg reported cheers from the audience at what he considered to be all the wrong moments—"When Belfort — a drug addict attempting to remain sober — rips up a couch cushion to get to his secret coke stash, there were cheers."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/banker-pros-cheer-wolf-of-wall-street-2013-12|title=Banker Pros Cheer At Wolf Of Wall Street|publisher=Business Insider|date=19 December 2013|accessdate=12 February 2014}}</ref><!-- 2nd ref shows [[WP:NOTABLE]] --><ref name="vf">{{cite web|date=26 December 2013|author=Katey Rich|title=The Wolf of Wall Street Is Enraging Moviegoers, Thrilling Bankers, And Making Tons Of Cash|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/online/oscars/2013/12/the-wolf-of-wall-street-christmas-box-office|quote=meaning audiences liked it less than everything else currently in theaters}}</ref>
The former [[Assistant United States Attorney]] who prosecuted the real Belfort criticized both the movie and the book on which it is based. He said he believes some of Belfort's claims were "invented", as for instance "[Belfort] aggrandized his importance and reverence for him by others at his firm." He strongly criticizes the film for not depicting the "thousands of [scam] victims who lost hundreds of millions of dollars", not accepting the filmmakers' argument that it would have detracted attention from the wrongdoers. Furthermore, he deplores the ending—"beyond an insult" to his victims—in which the real Belfort appears, while showing "a large sign advertising the name of Mr. Belfort's real motivational speaking company", and a positive depiction of Belfort uttering "variants of the same falsehoods he trained others to use against his victims".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cohen|first1=Joel M.|title=The Real Belfort Story Missing From 'Wolf' Movie|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/01/07/the-real-belfort-story-missing-from-wolf-movie/?_r=0|accessdate=9 November 2014|publisher=New York Times|date=7 January 2014}}</ref>
===Accolades=== {{Anchor|Awards|Accolades}} {{Main article|List of accolades received by The Wolf of Wall Street (2013 film)}} The film was nominated for five [[Academy Awards]]: [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]], [[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]] for Scorsese, [[Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay|Best Adapted Screenplay]] for Winter, [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] for DiCaprio, and [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]] for Hill. It was also nominated for four [[British Academy Film Awards|BAFTAs]], including Best Director, Best Actor and Best Adapted Screenplay, and two [[Golden Globe Award]]s, including [[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy|Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy]]. DiCaprio won the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy]].
==Soundtrack== {{Anchor|Music|Score|Soundtrack}} {{Infobox album | name = The Wolf of Wall Street: Music from the Motion Picture | type = Soundtrack | artist = Various artists | cover = | alt = | released = {{Start date|2013|12|17}}<br />{{small|(Digital download)}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = 56:30 | label = [[Virgin Records]] | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }}
The soundtrack to ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' features both original as well as existing music tracks, and was released on December 17, 2013 for digital download.
More than sixty songs were used in the film, but only sixteen were included on the official soundtrack. Notably, among the exceptions are original compositions by [[Theodore Shapiro (composer)|Theodore Shapiro]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Jagernauth|first=Kevin|title=All The Songs In 'The Wolf Of Wall Street' Including Devo, Cypress Hill, Foo Fighters & More|publisher=[[Indiewire]]|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/all-the-songs-in-the-wolf-of-wall-street-including-devo-cypress-hill-foo-fighters-more-20131227}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Thomas Mellon Evans | image = | caption = | birth_date = September 8, 1910 | birth_place = [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] | death_date = {{d-da|July 17, 1997|September 8, 1910}} | death_place = [[Manhattan]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = Manhattan, New York, [[Gainesville, Virginia]] | education = [[Shady Side Academy]],
[[Yale University]] | occupation = Financier, racehorse owner/breeder | known_for = | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | boards = Evans & Company, Evans Broadcasting Corp., [[H.K. Porter, Inc.]], [[Crane Co.]], [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame|National Museum of Racing]] | children = 1) Thomas Jr.
2) [[Edward P. Evans]]
3) Robert S. Evans | parents = | awards = New York Turf Writers Association Outstanding Breeder Award (1981)
Virginia Thoroughbred Association Hall of Fame (1993) | imagesize = | spouse = 1) Elizabeth Jane Parker (divorced 1953)
2) Josephine Schlotman Mitchell (1953-1977)
3) Betty Blackmond Barton Ready Loomis (married 1977) | relations = }} '''Thomas Mellon Evans''' (September 8, 1910 – July 17, 1997) was a [[financier]] who was one of the early [[corporate raid]]ers in [[United States|American]] business[http://alumninet.yale.edu/classes/yc1964/remembrances/evans.htm Yale University reprint of January 5, 2011 Washington Post article] as well as a [[philanthropist]] and a prominent [[Thoroughbred]] racehorse owner and breeder who won the 1981 [[Kentucky Derby]] and [[Preakness Stakes]].[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1124494/index.htm Sports Illustrated - May 3, 1981] ==Pioneer takeover specialist== Born James Evans in [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]], to Thomas Mellon Evans and Martha Jarnagin, his mother had his name changed to honor his recently deceased father in 1913. Evans's great-grandmother Elinor was the sister of Thomas Mellon, the father of the wealthy financier, [[Andrew W. Mellon]].''The White Sharks of Wall Street'': by Diana B. Henriques Orphaned as a young boy, Thomas was sent to stay with his mother's relatives in [[Tennessee]] before returning to Pittsburgh to live with his mother's sister. She and her husband were affluent enough to provide Thomas with a quality education and he graduated from the [[Shady Side Academy]] private school in 1927 [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NL8aAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KkoEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2691,5413670&dq=thomas-mellon-evans+shady+side+academy&hl=en Pittsburgh Press - June 17, 1927] and [[Yale University]] in 1931.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bx4cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Wn0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=1958,3606813&dq=thomas-mellon-evans+yale+university&hl=en Sarasota Herald-Tribune - July 19, 1997] For a few years after finishing university, Thomas Evans held a clerical job at [[Gulf Oil]], owned at the time by the [[Mellon family]]. Ambitious, he saved as much money as he could from his salary and together with a small inheritance, set out on his own. In 1939, he was able to purchase the bankrupt H.K. Porter, Inc., a manufacturer of light-duty [[Locomotive|railroad locomotives]] that he would diversify into the steel, hardware, and construction material business before converting the company into a [[holding company|holding corporation]] that would, during Evans time, take over more than eighty U.S. companies.[http://www.post-gazette.com/books/reviews/20000723review530.asp Pittsburgh Post-Gazette - July 23,2000] Among his major acquisitions was the 1959 takeover of [[Crane Co.]] of [[Chicago]], then a large valve and plumbing fixture manufacturer. In April 1959 Evans was appointed [[Chairman of the Board]] and [[Chief executive officer]] of the company. [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/djreprints/access/110517107.html?dids=110517107:110517107&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Apr+29%2C+1959&author=&pub=Wall+Street+Journal&desc=Crane+Co.+Names+Evans+Chairman%2C+Top+Officer+As+President+Resigns&pqatl=google Wall Street Journal - April 29, 1959] As of the end of 2011, his son Robert is Chairman of the Board of Crane Co.[http://ir.craneco.com/directors.cfm Crane.co website] and remains the largest individual shareholder in the company.[https://finance.yahoo.com/q/mh?s=CR+Major+Holders Yahoo Finance - retrieved November 22, 2011] The July 23, 2000, edition of the ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'' said that Thomas Mellon Evans was "arguably one of the seminal figures of 20th-century business."[http://www.post-gazette.com/books/reviews/20000723review530.asp ''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette'' - July 23,2000] Evans' story was told by [[Diana B. Henriques]] in her book ''The White Sharks of Wall Street: Thomas Mellon Evans and the Original Corporate Raiders'' published by [[Charles Scribner's Sons|Scribner]] in 2000 ({{ISBN|0684833999}} - Library of Congress Online Catalog). ==Buckland Farm== In 1956, Evans bought a 495-acre cattle farm in [[Gainesville, Virginia]], and converted it to a Thoroughbred breeding operation under the name Buckland Farm. The farm was managed and directed by Don M. Robertson, General Manager of the farm and a Vice President of its incorporation. Robertson, a Central Kentucky native whose family heritage consisted of a long line of excellent Thoroughbred horsemen, chose the matches between stallions and mares for Buckland Farm. It was Robertson who produced the winning bloodlines for the farm, including Pleasant Colony.[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C05E7DE1F38F93BA25754C0A961958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=print New York Times - July 18, 1997] During Evans' years in racing, [[Horse trainer|trainers]] who conditioned his horses included [[John P. Campo|John Campo]], [[Angel Cordero Jr.]], [[Leroy Jolley]], Ross Pearce, and Christopher Speckert. In addition to [[Pleasant Colony]], Thomas Evans owned a number of [[Graded stakes race|stakes]] winners including [[Pleasant Stage]], winner of the 1991 [[Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies]] and [[American Champion Two-Year-Old Filly]], plus the 1992 [[American Champion Older Male Horse]], [[Pleasant Tap]]. Thomas Evans was a member of the Board of Directors of the [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame]] and a member of [[The Jockey Club]], the [[Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Association]], and the Virginia Thoroughbred Association. In 1993, he was inducted into the Virginia Thoroughbred Association Hall of Fame.[http://www.vabred.org/halloffame.cfm Virginia Thoroughbred Association Hall of Fame] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220054942/http://www.vabred.org/halloffame.cfm |date=2012-02-20 }} Sons Edward and Robert became significant owners and/or breeders of Thoroughbred racehorses, with Robert owning the [[2014 Belmont Stakes]] winner [[Tonalist]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/more-sports/no-triple-crown-tonalist-wins-belmont-california-chrome-5th-article-1.1821086|title=No Triple Crown as Tonalist wins Belmont; California Chrome 4th|website=NY Daily News|access-date=2016-05-17}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.drf.com/news/family-ties-run-deep-belmont-winner-tonalist-owner-evans|title=Family ties run deep for Belmont winner Tonalist, owner Evans|website=Daily Racing Form|access-date=2016-05-17}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Evans, Thomas Mellon}} [[Category:1910 births]] [[Category:1997 deaths]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:American billionaires]] [[Category:American racehorse owners and breeders]] [[Category:Owners of Kentucky Derby winners]] [[Category:Owners of Preakness Stakes winners]] [[Category:American chief executives of financial services companies]] [[Category:American financiers]] [[Category:American investors]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:Corporate raiders]] [[Category:Mellon family]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Pittsburgh]] [[Category:Pennsylvania Republicans]] [[Category:Virginia Republicans]] [[Category:New York (state) Republicans]] [[Category:Shady Side Academy alumni]] [[Category:People from Gainesville, Virginia]]

{{Multiple issues| {{unreferenced|date=April 2015}} {{notability|date=April 2015}} {{Orphan|date=July 2016}} }} '''UIBS''' (short for '''US India Business Summit''') is an annual Business Expo between the [[United States|U.S.]] and India that is best known for its multidisciplinary speeches and panels, but is held only every other year. It is devoted to what it calls "Friendship and Business between the United States and India". The goal of UIBS is to promote business and investment between United States and India in key areas of technology, agriculture, healthcare, infrastructure, supply chain, logistics, real estate and investment etc. Our{{who|date=April 2015}} special emphasis is to connect entrepreneurs and small-to- medium size businesses. UIBS 2010 is organized by the [[Georgia Institute of Technology|Georgia Tech]] Center for International Business Education & Research (CIBER), USA India Initiatives, Inc. (USIII) and US India Business and Research Center (USIBRC) with support of [[Georgia Department of Economic Development]], the [[Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce]], US Commercial Services, and the [[US Department of Commerce]]. ==Background== UIBS 2010 is organized by Georgia Tech Center for International Business Education & Research (CIBER), USA India Initiatives, Inc. (USIII) and US India Business and Research Center (USIBRC) with support of [[Georgia Department of Economic Development]], the Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce, U.S. Commercial Service of [[United States of America]], [[Department of Commerce]]. The UIBS mission statement is:
The Goal of UIBS is to promote business and investment between USA and India in key areas of technology, agriculture, healthcare, infrastructure, supply chain, logistics, real estate and investment etc. Our special emphasis is to connect entrepreneurs and small-to- medium size businesses.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}

{{more citations needed|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox Newspaper | name = Upstream | image = | caption = | type = Weekly oil and gas industry newspaper, focusing on global upstream sector | format = [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|Tabloid]] | foundation = 1996 | ceased publication = | price = | owners = NHST Media Group | editor-in-chief = Erik Means | news editor = Mark Hillier | online editor = Anthea Pitt | assoceditor = | staff = 25 | language = [[English language|English]] | political = | circulation = 6585 (June 2007)
7078 (2008 average net circulation 1 January 2008-31 December 2008 according to Audit Bureau of Circulation) | headquarters = [[Oslo]], [[Norway]] | oclc = 223512583 | ISSN = 0807-6472 | website = {{url|https://www.upstreamonline.com}} }} '''''Upstream''''' is an independent oil and gas industry [[Upstream (petroleum industry)|upstream sector]] weekly newspaper and a daily internet news site. The newspaper is owned by [[NHST Media Group]]. It is headquartered in [[Oslo]], [[Norway]]. The newspaper covers the [[Upstream (petroleum industry)|upstream sector]] of the global [[oil and gas industry]] with full-time staff correspondents in all the major centres of the industry. It is published every Friday. Upstream had full-time reporters based in its head office in Oslo, as well as bureaux and correspondents in [[London]], [[Moscow]], [[Accra]], [[New Delhi]], [[Singapore]], [[Wellington]], [[Rio de Janeiro]] and [[Houston]]. Its editor in chief is Erik Means. {{cite news | last = Romero | first = Simon | title = One Journal Of Oil Industry Covers More Than Just Rigs | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = 2004-06-12 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/12/business/one-journal-of-oil-industry-covers-more-than-just-rigs.html?scp=1&sq=One%20Journal%20Of%20Oil%20Industry%20Covers%20More%20Than%20Just%20Rigs&st=cse | accessdate = 2011-11-16 }} The newspaper was founded in 1996 to compete with well-established rivals including ''[[Oil & Gas Journal]]'', ''[[Petroleum Intelligence Weekly]]'', and ''[[Offshore Engineer]]''. It covers all aspects of the upstream industry, but focuses especially on news related to business, policy and the sector's key players as well as the commercial side of the industry. Coverage includes exploration, field development, contracts, company news, technological developments and the liquefied natural gas sector, as well as political and financial news which affects the exploration and production sector. {{cite news | last = Calvo | first = Dana | title = Tabloid Swims Against Tide of Oil and Gas Industry | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = 2003-09-07 | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2003/sep/07/business/fi-houston7 | accessdate = 2011-11-16 }} In 2001, Upstream added an online edition, upstreamonline.com, which is updated 24 hours a day, five days a week from London, Oslo, Houston and Perth. It provides breaking news and online feature articles written by a dedicated online editorial team, as well as giving access to digital versions of the newspaper in various formats. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website}} [[Category:Publications established in 1996]] [[Category:Weekly newspapers published in Norway]] [[Category:Business newspapers]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Oslo]] [[Category:Petroleum magazines]] {{Norway-newspaper-stub}}
